image.altText: Woman in a green top and hat standing in a desert.

props.synopsis: Legal aid services in Alice Springs are experiencing a lawyer shortage, leaving some people who have been charged with crimes to navigate the justice system alone.

title.children: Indigenous Australians in Alice Springs face a legal crisis with potentially dire consequences

image.altText: Tropical cyclone forecast track map January 23

props.synopsis: The system is now forecast to cross the coast on Thursday between Cardwell and Airlie Beach.

title.children: Cyclone Kirrily expected to be declared overnight as it tracks slowly towards Queensland

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

props.synopsis: A new survey shows that nearly every Australian is cutting back on expenses — whether it be on entertainment or life's basics like food.

title.children: Evidence suggests households are under extreme cost-of-living stress, and a new worry is creeping in

image.altText: Mid shot of radiographer preparing woman for a mammogram.

props.synopsis: With one-in-seven Australian women likely to be diagnosed with breast cancer, concern is growing about the wait times for diagnostic mammograms around the country.

title.children: 'I've got this massive lump': Catching it is one thing, but women face 'scary' waitlists for diagnostic mammograms

image.altText: A female tennis player in a multicolour top punches the air and screams in victory

props.synopsis: Dayana Yastremska wins hearts, Daniil Medvedev entertains and a protest stops play. Here are five quick hits from day nine at Melbourne Park.

title.children: Five quick hits — Qualifier's dream run ends former champion's slam, while Medvedev charms with insightful interview

image.altText: Australian banknotes, mostly $50 bills, strewn over a flat surface.

props.synopsis: The median income earner will pay an extra $5,000 in the next three years but get minimal benefit from the stage 3 tax cuts, according to analysis by the independent Parliamentary Budget Office.

title.children: Low and middle income earners are set for a bracket creep crunch with little help from stage 3 tax cuts

image.altText: An aerial view of flooding at Timber Creek.

props.synopsis: Potential evacuations of remote communities with the help of the Australian Defence Force had been flagged by authorities but NT Chief Minister Eva Lawler says they are no longer required.

title.children: Floodwaters receding in NT communities while supply chain issues continue

image.altText: Smoke rises from a missile attack in Erbil

props.synopsis: The latest round of attack and response in the Middle East threatens to push the region into a broader war that has a common element ... Iran.

title.children: Iran's changing strategy sparks fear of regional war in the Middle East

image.altText: A graphic showing a man coughing, a rapid antigen COVID test and three spike proteins

props.synopsis: As school holidays come to an end and people return to work, Australians are reminded to take precautions against another "substantial" wave of COVID-19.

title.children: These three charts show the latest COVID-19 numbers from around Australia

image.altText: A crowd of people gathered outside a temple

props.synopsis: One of the most divisive chapters in India's history has come to an end with the opening of a new Hindu temple on the site where an ancient mosque was torn down. While Narendra Modi's supporters see it as a victory, Muslim Indians are fearful it could stoke old tensions.

title.children: How a Hindu temple built on the remains of an ancient mosque could help Modi win this year's election

image.altText: People holding protest signs crowd a room where people sit at a circular table

props.synopsis: Israeli forces have stormed a hospital and placed another under siege in the southern Gaza city of Khan Younis, as families of the Israeli hostages storm a parliamentary committee.

title.children: Families of Israeli hostages storm parliament demanding politicians do more to free loved ones

image.altText: A representation of virtual currency Bitcoin and US banknotes.

props.synopsis: The decision by the US Securities and Exchange Commission to approve bitcoin exchange-traded funds was a decade in the making that's legitimised crypto — and experts say it won't be long before Australia follows suit.

title.children: Bitcoin is legitimate risky business, but a decision to take it 'mainstream' in the US has destigmatised crypto

image.altText: Grace Tame wearing white shirt and looking at the camera

props.synopsis: The government has announced the parameters for an inquiry that could potentially overhaul judicial responses to sexual violence, with the report set to be released in a year's time.

title.children: Scope of federal government inquiry into the judicial response to sexual violence revealed

image.altText: Two young people looking at their phones.

props.synopsis: Timor-Leste has the fourth-slowest internet in the world, sitting just in front of Afghanistan, Yemen and Syria — and its young population is fed up.

title.children: It's 700km from Darwin but this country has the fourth-slowest internet in the world

image.altText: A drone shot looking down at a flooded road as a person in the distance walks through the water covering the road

props.synopsis: The year has barely started and extreme weather events are already in the headlines. Here are some more big environment issues to keep an eye on.

title.children: Coral bleaching, litigation and water rights are shaping up to be hot climate topics in 2024

image.altText: Donald Trump wears a suit and tie. He's smilnig at another man wearing a suit and tie.

props.synopsis: When it comes to political firepower, no organisation in the US has been as effective in influencing the gun debate as the National Rifle Association, but this month, the NRA is on trial in New York in a case that threatens how its future plays out.

title.children: Downfall of a behemoth: Wayne LaPierre is alleged to have embezzled millions. It's changed the NRA forever

image.altText: a mine site with a big truck and white rock

props.synopsis: The sudden evaporation of hype and hot air in the energy transition industry may leave many who plunged into critical minerals in a critical condition, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Will the crash in critical minerals derail the clean energy transition?

image.altText: Tiana Mangakahia is wearing a pink t-shirt that says 'pink hoops', she's spinning a basketball on her finger and smiles.

props.synopsis: After being re-diagnosed with breast cancer last year, Tiana Mangakahia says she now aims to 'live free', while embracing her new role as an assistant coach with the Sydney Flames in the WNBL.

title.children: Basketballer Tiana Mangakahia has found her purpose as she fights breast cancer again

image.altText: Graeme Innes speaks to the media.

props.synopsis: Australia's former disability discrimination commissioner Graeme Innes has settled a dispute with Adelaide Airport over a "humiliating and distressing" experience with security screening.

title.children: Complaint against Adelaide Airport settled with former disability discrimination commissioner

image.altText: Sophie Randall looks directly into the camera

props.synopsis: At just 13 years old, Sophie had a bad experience on the footy field, but is speaking out because she's proud of her Aboriginal heritage. It's a story experts say is too common.

title.children: Sophie was called a racist name on the footy field. She's not letting it bring her down

image.altText: Male tennis player, yellow top, holding his racquet and pumping his fist, yelling in delight.

props.synopsis: World number two Carlos Alcaraz has made it through to his first quarterfinal at Melbourne Park following a straight-sets masterclass against Miomir Kecmanovic.

title.children: Carlos Alcaraz produces a near-flawless performance in dominant victory

image.altText: Two images put together, left side Richard in work uniform, right side Richard in a hospital gown.

props.synopsis: Melanoma expert Richard Scolyer is thrilled with his latest scan results, which come eight months after being diagnosed with "the worst of the worst" brain cancer.

title.children: Richard Scolyer celebrates positive news, months after 'certain death' diagnosis

image.altText: Two men and woman stand over big maps with books laid out

props.synopsis: The rescue of a man and his dog from floodwaters in Victoria has highlighted a shortage of State Emergency Service volunteers in regional and rural areas, with it taking an hour for a non-local unit to get to the scene.

title.children: Hour-long wait for flood rescue highlights issue of regional towns that don't have an SES unit

image.altText: A serious young woman on the floor next to a wall covered in painted handprints, wears orange, white t-shirt, black pants.

props.synopsis: The vibrant handprint display tells hundreds of unique stories about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander histories and culture and unites some of the country's most respected Indigenous trailblazers.

title.children: Angel never thought she'd see her niece again, then she saw a handprint at her high school

image.altText: A person covering their face as a liquid is sprayed towards them by several police officers.

props.synopsis: Ten people have been arrested as dozens of activists clash with Victoria police at a pro-Palestinian rally at the Port of Melbourne.

title.children: Pro-Palestinian activists clash with police at Port of Melbourne

image.altText: A male cricketer, wearing teal and black, raises his bat to thank the crowd as he leaves the field.

props.synopsis: Brisbane Heat opener Josh Brown pulverises a tournament-record 12 sixes to go with 10 fours in his 57-ball 140.

title.children: Josh Brown smashes record century to send Brisbane Heat to BBL final

image.altText: Roger Rogerson, a man wearing glasses, blazer and shirt leaves a building

props.synopsis: The life of disgraced former NSW detective Roger Rogerson has come to an end. But the former cop's passing leaves many unanswered questions.

title.children: The secrets Roger Rogerson has taken to his grave

image.altText: A man's hand holds a teaspoon of sunscreen

props.synopsis: Experts say you should be using at least 35 millilitres of sunscreen every day. And if you get sweaty, you'll need to reapply.

title.children: Are you slapping on the recommended seven teaspoons of sunscreen each day?
